results.title: A Personal search
results.brief_description: In this autobiographical documentary, John Whitney, one of the best-known film and computer artists of our time, reflects on and explores his lifelong search for the complentarity of music and visual art, and the synthesis of film and computer technologies. In doing so, he describes current developments that foretell radical and exciting new ways viewers will soon be experiencing music and art.

results.title: Permutations
results.brief_description:
An early example of computer generated animation; several hundred dots move about the screen according to a set of
instructions in a graphics program which were input into a
IBM digital computer and coloured by an optical printer.
‘Action sequences, proceeding from order to disorder and back to ordered patterning, suggest a parallel to harmonic phenomena of the musical scale … The effect is to subtly generate and resolve tension - which is similar to the primary emotional power of music composition’ (John Whitney).

results.title: Matrix
results.brief_description: Another of John Whitney’s important investigations into technology and the moving image, this particularly geometric animated abstraction uses industrial computers to render Whitney’s light musical forms onto the screen. Computer generated forms evolve, merge and subdivide on a black background, each motion and movement as carefully orchestrated and synthesised as the accompanying music.

results.title: Dreamland: a history of early Canadian movies 1895-1939
results.creator_credit: Kirwan Cox, Donald Brittain and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: People have become so sated with spectacular inventions and achievements that it is now difficult to imagine the sensation created by the first motion picture films, in which people actually moved about on the screen just as in real life. Little is left of those early days of Canadian cinema. But from the footage available, the filmmakers have pieced together an absorbing account of what went on the screens of the nation in those times, and of the people who influenced the fledgling industry. This is a flashback to the past that all will enjoy.
results.title_for_label: Dreamland: a history of early Canadian movies 1895-1939

results.title: Dreamland express
results.brief_description: David Anderson’s waking dream is a poetic animated journey through the rich fantasy life of a child’s unconscious, combining elaborate cut-outs, intricate drawn cell animation and live action. A young boy finds himself in a mysterious express train travelling through a forbodeing and surreal landscape.

results.title: Dreamings : the art of Aboriginal Australia
results.creator_credit: Michael Riley, Janet Bell and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Dreamings is a journey into the lush mangroves and scarred heartlands of Australia to see traditional aboriginal artists at work. From the air we view some of the landforms and waterways incorporated in the imagery of paintings by Michael Nelson Jakamarra. He talks of his family’s association with the land and his intrinsic faith in spiritual connections with animals and plants. Our voyage continues to the Great Western Desert and a sacred waterhole. This program begins to unravel some of the mysteries behind creations of immense artistic beauty.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Riley, Janet Bell and Film Australia

results.title: Dress for Success
results.brief_description: Each year the final students at Sydney’s design colleges compete for a fashion design award. In 1991 the theme was for an evening dress which reflected the multicultural heritage of Australia. The judges, students and teachers comment on the designs themselves, the state of the fashion industry in Australia and their own personal hopes and dreams.

results.title: Glen Keane interview with Emma McRae [excerpt]
results.brief_description: Glen Keane has been with the Walt Disney Studios for over 25 years and is best known for his character animations for feature films such as: ‘The Little Mermaid’, ‘Aladdin’, ‘Beauty and the Beast’, ‘Tarzan’, and ‘Tangled’. In this interview, Emma McRae, ACMI Exhibitions Curator, speaks to Glen about his never-ending passion for drawing, what inspires him to create such unforgettable characters as The Beast and Ariel. Glen also talks about the changes in animation from hand drawn to digital.
